Electrospinning technique was exploited to prepare a series of nickel-manganese alloy on carbon nanofibers [NiMn@CNFs] in various Ni:Mn wt.% ratios by using the corresponding acetate salts at 20 kV, followed by a calcination process for the obtained metallic fibrous mats at 850 °C for 5 h. The crystalline structure, morphology and chemical constituents of formed nanocomposites were determined by using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyses. The electrocatalytic activity of different NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials for oxidizing ethylene glycol molecules was evaluated in NaOH solution through cyclic voltammetry and steady state polarization measurements. The presence of increased content of manganese in NiMn@CNFs nanocomposite significantly affected its electrochemical performance. Adding 40 wt.% Mn in the synthesized nanomaterial was sufficient to achieve the optimum oxidation current density with the best stability when compared to that of Ni@CNFs. The present work opens a new route for fabricating many binary and ternary transition metals-based fibrous mats by using the electrospinning technique and examining their electrochemical activity for renewable energy applications. Keywords Optimum performance Ethylene glycol electro-oxidation Electrospinning technique Nickel-based nanomaterials Alkaline solution 1 Introduction The increased practical power density, lowered toxicity and limited crossover of applied fuel can be considered as the main advantages of direct alcohol fuel cells as effective power sources in near future [1–4]. Ethylene glycol represents a promising fuel with higher energy density [7.56 kWh L−1] and boiling point [198 °C] when compared to those of mainly used candidates including methanol and ethanol. The choice of a suitable anode material with a favored morphology and an optimum electronic structure is an urgent demand for the electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications [5–8]. An increased surface area and short diffusion paths for fast and easy mass transport process are the basic requirements of examined catalytic supports [9,10]. They should be also nontoxic, cheap and have numerous surface functional groups that can act as active anchoring sites for the deposited multi-metallic components with an efficient structural ability for reducing the nanoparticles agglomeration [11]. In this respect, Pt and Pd-based nanocatalysts were examined for oxidizing ethylene glycol molecules [12–19]. Pt−Pd−Co nanoflowers were prepared by a solvothermal method by using oleylamine and cetylpyridinium chloride as reducing and shape-directing agents, respectively. They displayed enhanced oxidation current density values when compared to the obtained results at commercial Pt and Pd black materials beside PtPd and PtPdCo nanoparticles [20]. Core-shell PtPd@Pt nanoparticles were deposited onto reduced graphene oxide by using formic acid. Increased tolerance towards ethylene glycol oxidation reaction in both acidic and alkaline solutions was measured when compared to the obtained results at Pt and Pd nanocatalysts onto commercial carbon support [21]. A wet-chemical method was applied for preparing PdAu nanoparticles by using poly(1-vinyl-3-ethylimidazolium bromide) as a structure-directing agent. The best electrocatalytic performance was recorded at the nanocatalyst containing Pd:Au atomic ratio of 1:3. The alloyed nature and the specific snowflake-like shape of PdAu nanocatalyst in addition to its good stability against corrosion could explain this outstanding activity [22]. Although Pt-based nanomaterials showed extraordinary activities towards ethylene glycol oxidation, their rare natural sources might limit the wide application on the commercial scale [23]. Additionally, some poisonous byproducts would be accumulated on the electrodes surfaces after prolonged operation periods in acidic solutions to retard the rate of further electro-oxidation process [24–26]. These obstacles have directed many scientists to investigate the activity of another metallic nanocatalysts for oxidizing ethylene glycol molecules in alkaline solution. The enhanced electrochemical activity of nickel, the increased resistance towards corrosion processes in aggregated electrolytes and its low cost when compared to noble metals might encourage many scientists to explore its performance when it is applied as an active material in many important applications. Accordingly, many nickel-based nanomaterials were prepared in the last few years and their electrocatalytic activities were examined [27–39]. Lowered onset potential and overpotential values of 1.430 and 0.249 V were, respectively measured during oxygen evolution reaction at pyrolyzed FeCoNi nanoparticles onto bamboo-like N-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) at 10 mA cm−2 [40]. Moreover, Ni0.25Cu0.75/C nanoparticles showed an outstanding long-term stability performance by keeping 90% of their initial current after 20,000 s during continuous oxygen reduction, oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions [41]. Some efficient anode materials could be constituted from porous carbon and reduced graphene oxide as carbonaceous supports with doping metallic oxide species and nickel nanoparticles as active components. An excellent oxidation current density of 626 mA mg−1 was measured in alkaline solution containing 1.0 M alcohol [42]. Electrodeposited nickel nanoparticles inside poly(m-toluidine) on carbon paste electrode surface exhibited an increased rate constant during ethylene glycol oxidation reaction as 2.1 × 106 cm3 mol−1s−1. The nanomaterial synthesis parameters including the monomer concentration, polymer thickness and nickel electrodeposition time could significantly control its electroactivity [43]. Manganese and its various oxides are widely doped into the chemical structure of certain nanocatalysts in order to increase their electrochemical active surface area. Manganese is a cheap metal with many abundant resources. The low toxicity and high specific capacitance of manganese-based nanomaterials enable them to act as good protecting coatings in magnetic memory media and micro-electro-mechanical systems [44–49] in addition to their enhanced activity in energy storage fields such as supercapacitors, primary and rechargeable batteries [50,51]. However, the poor electronic conductivity of these nanomaterials might limit their efficient utilization [52,53]. Therefore, extensive research articles are planning to tackle these drawbacks by fabricating bimetallic materials with specific morphology and controlled microstructure [54,55] including Mn with an active transition metal such as Cu [56,57], Co [58–61] and Zn [62,63]. Nickel-manganese nanocomposites and their mixed oxides have been investigated for electro-oxidizing fuels such as methanol [64–69], ethanol [70,71], urea [72,73], sodium borohydride [74] and glucose [75–77] in addition to their surprising activities during supercapacitors measurements [78–84]. In-situ removal and co-precipitation methods were exploited to prepare Mn doped Ni(OH)2 nanosheets. Introducing Mn to Ni(OH)2 could explain its enhanced activity for oxidizing methanol molecules by promoting the formation of a higher oxidation state of nickel and improving the nanomaterial conductivity [68]. Abbas et al [69]. have measured an increased methanol oxidation current density of 110.34 mA cm−2 at NiC−MnC@CNFs when nickel acetate: manganese acetate ratio of 90:10 was incorporated into the fabricated nanocomposite. Danaee et al [65]. have estimated a diffusion coefficient value of 4 × 10−6 cm2 s−1 for methanol molecules at the surface of galvanostatically deposited nickel-manganese alloy onto graphite electrode. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopic study of encapsulated nickel-manganese salen complex inside zeolite A mesopores demonstrated that by varying the chosen potential, the rate-determining step of methanol oxidation reaction gradually changed from the electro-oxidation step with forming adsorbed intermediates at the electrode surface at lowered potential values to the desorption of these byproducts via oxidation when higher potentials were applied. Accelerated reaction rates were also observed when the added methanol concentration to the supporting electrolyte increased as concluded from the decreased semicircles diameter in the corresponding Nyquist plots [67]. The electrocatalytic activity of chemically reduced nickel ions onto MnOx/C surface using sodium borohydride with subjecting the formed powder to the microwave irradiation was investigated for electro-oxidizing methanol molecules in KOH solution. The maximum activity and stability were attained at the nanocatalyst containing 7.5 wt.% manganese oxide [66]. Nakayama et al [71]. have measured a mass activity value of 4.30 kA g-Ni −1 when anchored nickel ions inside the interstitial sites of layered MnO2 were examined for ethanol electro-oxidation in alkaline solution. It was 4.62 folds higher than that shown at thin α-Ni(OH)2 film. Alajami et al [73]. have studied the influence of varying the synthesis conditions of Ni−Mn nanoparticles onto carbon nanofibers on the obtained electrochemical activity. Adding poly(vinyl alcohol) during the electrospinning process significantly increased the measured electrical conductivity of modified carbon nanofibers with nickel-manganese nanoparticles. Moreover, increasing the calcination temperature of the fabricated nanomaterial gradually shifted the observed onset potential for urea oxidation reaction from 590 mV at 550 °C towards more negative values by 120, 160 and 150 mV at 700, 850 and 1000 ° C, respectively. A stable behavior over 20 h was observed at NiMnO3 when oxygen gas was evolved reaching a decreased overpotential value of 256 mV versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) at 10 mA cm−2 [80]. When mixed nickel-manganese oxide nanoflakes were supported onto graphene oxide, a decreased Tafel slope value of 47.84 mV dec−1 was measured during oxygen evolution reaction in KOH solution at 10 mA cm−2 within a long stability period of 28,800 s [85]. The decoration of reduced graphene oxide with spinel NiMn2O4 nanosheets resulted in an increased sensitivity of 78.56 mA mM−1 cm−2 towards acetylacetone determination within a wide linear concentration range of 1.0−500.0 µM [82]. Based on this good activity of Ni−Mn based nanomaterials, a series of supported xNi(1−x)Mn nanoparticles onto carbon nanofibers was fabricated using the electrospinning technique for their acetate mixtures in presence of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) solution (PVP) with subsequent calcination in argon gas flow at 850 °C. Formed NiMn@CNFs nanocatalysts were electrochemically investigated to oxidize ethylene glycol molecules in NaOH solution. Incorporating Mn in the chemical structure of Ni@CNFs appreciably enhanced the fuel oxidation kinetics. Increasing the number of nickel active sites with their uniform arrangement onto CNFs surface resulted in optimum electrocatalytic platforms for oxidizing the alcohol molecules. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials Two stock solutions of nickel acetate [NiAc, 98% assay, Sigma-Aldrich Co., USA] and manganese acetate [MnAc, 99% assay, Sigma-Aldrich Co., USA] were individually prepared by dissolving 5 g of each precursor salt into 25 mL distilled water with continuous stirring until clear solutions were obtained. PVP solution [with average molecular weight of 1,300,000 g mol−1, DC Chemical Co., South Korea] was then prepared by introducing a defined weight of its powder into ethanol [70%, Sigma-Aldrich Co., USA] to have 15 wt.% of polymeric species into the alcoholic solvent. Varied mixtures of NiAc−MnAc were homogenized into wt.% ratios of 100:0, 60:40, 55:45, 50:50, 45:55 and 35:65. PVP solution was separately added to each bimetallic acetate mixture into 4 folds wt.% value. The temperature of these solutions was raised up to 50 °C using a water bath with steady stirring for 5 h until a clear sol-gel was formed. A lab-scale electrospinning machine was employed to fabricate incorporated carbon nanofibrous mats with metallic species. A voltage value of 20 kV was adjusted and the distance between the coated cylindrical drum with polyethylene sheet and the flow collector tip was 15 cm. The obtained nanomaterials were inserted into a vacuum oven and heated for 24 h at 50 °C. A calcination step was then carried out using an argon atmosphere within a holding period of 5 h at 850 °C. Supported CNFs with Ni−Mn nanoparticles were designated as ×Ni(100−×)Mn@CNFs, where × could be 35, 45, 50, 55 and 60. Ni@CNFs was referring to a manganese free nanopowder. 2.2 Characterization of formed NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials XRD, SEM, TEM, EDX and Raman analysis tools were exploited to fully define the synthesized binary metallic nickel−manganese nanocatalysts onto CNFs. A certain diffractometer (Rigaku Co., Japan) was employed and its wavelength was adjusted for radiated Cu Kα at 1.54056 Å to explore the corresponding XRD charts of all NiMn@CNFs nanopowders. Hitachi S-7400 scanning electron microscope could efficiently determine the basic morphological features of examined nanocatalysts. An additional pictorial view for their nanofibrous nature was studied through transmission electron microscopy (JEOL TEM-2200FS). Energy dispersive X-ray spectrophotometer (JEOL Ltd., Japan) was used to detect the actually active components in 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanocomposite and their distribution onto the formed surface. Raman spectra of CNFs and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanopowders were also measured using a laser excitation with a wavelength at 532 nm. 2.3 Electrocatalytic measurements of NiMn@CNFs activity Autolab N128 was applied to study the electrochemical performance of Ni@CNFs and different NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials for oxidizing ethylene glycol molecules in NaOH solution. An electrochemical three-electrodes based cell was connected to this potentiostat. Its working electrode was a glassy carbon (GC) surface after its modification with the formed nanomaterial. To prepare this coated electrode, the used surface was first polished by ultrafine slurries of alumina with subsequent cleaning by double distilled water and ethanol. The examined nanomaterial was casted onto GC surface by suspending 2 mg into a mixture of 20 µL Nafion and 420 µL isopropanol and sonicating this ink at 40 °C for 30 min. A certain volume of this mixture [15 µL] was inserted onto the polished carbon surface and left to dry inside an air oven at 80 °C for 10 min. Beside this modified working electrode, Ag/AgCl/3 M KCl system was used as the reference electrode, while the counter electrode was Pt wire. An activation step of Ni@CNFs and NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials onto GC electrode was necessary before carrying out the electrochemical measurements. Here, the electrode surface was continuously cyclized for about 50 cycles in 1.0 M NaOH solution at 100 mV s−1 in a defined potential region [starting from −-200 mV and ending at 1000 mV] to finally have a stable cyclic voltammogram. Some important kinetic parameters could be calculated for Ni@CNFs and different NiMn@CNFs nanocatalysts in NaOH solution including their electron transfer coefficient (α), electron transfer rate constant (ks, s−1) and surface coverage (Γ*, mol. cm−2) values. The electrochemical activity of these nanocomposites for ethylene glycol electro-oxidation reaction was studied by using cyclic voltammetry and chronoamperometry techniques. Different alcohol concentrations were added to NaOH solution and the corresponding cyclic voltammograms were measured. Constant potential experiments were also conducted in NaOH solution before and after introducing the fuel molecules to explore the related stability of Ni@CNFs and all NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials after operation for long time. All electrochemical studies were carried out in air at 30 °C. 3 Results and discussion SEM images of bare CNFs, Ni@CNFs and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanomaterials were presented in Fig. 1 A−C, respectively. A continuous nanofibrous structure was clearly observed for all formed nanopowders. Metallic nanoparticles were also detected on the external surfaces of CNFs in Ni@CNFs and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs samples in a uniform arrangement [see Fig. 1B, C]. The diameter distribution diagrams of a number of CNFs, Ni@CNFs and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanofibers were presented in Fig. 2 . They all displayed a wide range of diameter values with the most predominated one at 450, 170 and 150 nm for CNFs [Fig. 2A], Ni@CNFs [Fig. 2B] and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs [Fig. 2C] nanomaterials, respectively. This observation demonstrated that the presence of metallic precursor salts in the preparation mixture of CNFs has its preferential effect in reducing the diameter of formed nanofibers. Decreased nanofiber diameters were still measured after incorporating MnAc. Abbas et al [69]. have concluded that the average diameter values of NiC−MnC@CNFs nanomaterials were appreciably related to the introduced content of MnAc in the electrospinning solution. The graphitization degree and the extent of structural defects of carbon-based nanomaterials could be derived by calculating IG/ID as the ratio for the intensity of G-band to that of the D-band [92,108]. A redox peak was observed at Ni@CNFs at potential values of 488 and 294 mV in the anodic and cathodic directions, respectively. Its appearance was related to Ni(II)/Ni(III) transformation based on the following equation [113–116]: (1) Ni ( OH ) 2 + O H − ↔ NiOOH + H 2 O + e − The position of this redox couple was cathodically shifted in almost all prepared NiMn@CNFs nanocatalysts. The related Ep values of Ni(II)/Ni(III) redox couple for Ni@CNFs and all NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials were shown in Table 3 . Moreover, increasing manganese content in the formed nanopowder [as predicted in 50Ni50Mn@CNFs, 45Ni55Mn@CNFs and 35Ni65Mn@CNFs] resulted in a splitted Ni(OH)2/NiOOH redox couple into two small peaks in the oxidation and reduction directions. Cycling nickel-containing nanocatalysts in alkaline solution would oxidize metallic nickel to two forms as hydrous α-Ni(OH)2 and anhydrous β-Ni(OH)2 [117]. This phenomenon could explain the observed two little peaks in the forward scan for NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials with increased Mn wt.% ratios. This unstable α-form of nickel hydroxide was gradually converted to a more stable β-form when the examined nanomaterial was continuously cyclized for long time [118]. Further scan of this electrode towards more positive potential values would oxidize β-Ni(OH)2 into β-NiOOH. This nickel oxyhydroxide form was partially accumulated on the nanomaterial surface as γ-NiOOH [119]. Moreover, β- and α-Ni(OH)2 forms would be produced in the backward direction by reducing β and γ-species of nickel oxyhydroxide, respectively. A slight potential shift in the negative direction was noticed for the reduction peak of NiOOH into Ni(OH)2 in the backward scan as increased cycles of the formed nanomaterials were studied in alkaline solution. Furthermore, the current density value regularly increased as the number of scanned cycles increased due to the progressive building up of converted Ni(OH)2/NiOOH particles on the nanocatalysts surfaces [124]. The electroactive surface area (ESA) values of Ni@CNFs and NiMn@CNFs nanocatalysts were calculated according to the following equation [125–127]: (4) ESA = Q / sl Here, ‘Q’ is the needed charge to convert the produced NiOOH particles on the electrode surface to Ni(OH)2 and ‘s’ is the required charge to form a one monolayer of Ni(OH)2 [257 μC cm−2] [128–130]. On the other hand, ‘l’ is the metal loading in the investigated nanomaterial in g cm−2. ESA values of Ni@CNFs, 60Ni40Mn@CNFs, 55Ni45Mn@CNFs, 50Ni50Mn@CNFs, 45Ni55Mn@CNFs and 35Ni65Mn@CNFs nanocatalysts were 2.380, 16.756, 10.036, 8.770, 11.432 and 7.310 m2 g−1, respectively as listed in Table 4 . Based on Laviron′s laws [134], α and ks values were calculated using the following relations: (5) E pa = E o + RT / { ( 1 − α ) nF } × ln { ( 1 − α ) nF υ / RT k s } (6) E pc = E o + RT / ( α nF ) × ln ( α nF υ / RT k s ) (7) ln k s = α ln ( 1 − α ) + ( 1 − α ) ln α − ln ( RT / nF υ ) − α ( 1 − α ) nF Δ E / RT Here in these equations, the potential values of anodic and cathodic peaks of Ni(II)/Ni(III) transition redox couple are, respectively represented by Epa and Epc, while Eo stands for the standard electrode potential. The stability of Ni@CNFs and NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials was examined during working in alkaline solution for long periods. The related chronoamperograms were demonstrated in Fig. 13 A, B in 4.0 M NaOH solution before and after adding 1.0 M ethylene glycol. This study was carried out at 350 mV for 3600 s. A sudden current density drop was observed at the first few seconds of these chronoamperograms followed by a relatively stable performance. Ahmed et al [76]. have explained this decay based on the rapid alcohol molecules oxidation near the electrode surface with a further change in the reaction kinetics to a mass transfer-controlled step. Generally, these steady current densities in blank solution were much lower than those measured after adding ethylene glycol molecules. The bar diagrams in Fig. 13C could illustrate these stable values for Ni@CNFs and all NiMn@CNFs nanocatalysts in 4.0 M NaOH solution in absence and in presence of 1.0 M ethylene glycol at 1800 s. The oxidation current densities could be arranged in a descending order as follows: 60Ni40Mn@CNFs [7.612 mA cm−2] > 45Ni55Mn@CNFs [3.818 mA cm−2] ≅ 55Ni45Mn@CNFs [3.809 mA cm−2] > 50Ni50Mn@CNFs [3.194 mA cm−2] > 35Ni65Mn@CNFs [2.038 mA cm−2] >> Ni@CNFs [0.448 mA cm−2]. When the ratio of the steady state current density of fabricated nanocatalysts in NaOH solution was calculated in presence of ethylene glycol molecules to that of blank electrolyte [I(ethylene glycol+blank) / Iblank], NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials containing increased Mn wt.% values exhibited better stability behavior of Ni(III) ions active sites when ethylene glycol molecules were oxidized in relation to that of Ni@CNFs [Ni@CNFs [12.23 folds], 35Ni65Mn@CNFs [14.61 folds], 45Ni55Mn@CNFs [18.81 folds] and 50Ni50Mn@CNFs [33.87 folds]]. Barakat et al [72]. have concluded that the nanofibrous structure of Ni&Mn nanodeposits on CNFs was responsible for the improved stability behavior of nanocatalysts containing certain Ni:Mn ratios. After subjecting 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanomaterial surface to this chronoamperometry test, its morphology and composition were studied using respective SEM and EDX analysis techniques in Fig. 14 . The nanofibrous structure of 60Ni40Mn@CNFs was still observed without subsequent cracks formation or nanofibers fragmentations after the stability test [see Fig. 14A, B]. The main nanocatalyst chemical composition was also preserved as confirmed by its EDX chart in Fig. 14C with slightly unchanged wt.% ratios of the elemental constituents. This obtained result for the stability experiment at Ni@CNFs and all NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials strongly supported their suitability for efficient working in fuel cells applications within long time periods. To highlight the improved electrocatalytic performance of our prepared Ni@CNFs and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanomaterials, a comparison was listed in Table 6 with the electrochemical parameters of fuel electro-oxidation process at some related Ni-based nanocatalysts in previous reports [36,139−143]. This table included Eonset, Ep, Ip, Isteady, investigated fuel, tested solution and fabrication method for the studied electrodes. Outstanding results were generally noticed in Eonset, Ep, Ip and Isteady values at 60Ni40Mn@CNFs when compared to those at the stated nanomaterials in Table 6. For example, Eonset for ethylene glycol oxidation reaction at 60Ni40Mn@CNFs was 249 and 293 mV more negative than that shown at 2D NiO porous nanosheets [at 450 °C] [140] and NiMoS2-15/MXene [141], respectively. Moreover, the measured Ep values at Ni@CNFs and 60Ni40Mn@CNFs were lower than those at Cu/Ni modified microporous film by 168 and 82 mV, respectively [142]. Much increased oxidation current density was also observed at 60Ni40Mn@CNFs when compared to that at NiMoS2–15/MXene (1.93 mA cm−2) [141], Ni−P/C (6.40 mA cm−2) [36] and NiS@CNFs (12.00 mA cm−2) [143]. Furthermore, better stability performance was shown by 60Ni40Mn@CNFs when operated for longer time than those of all studied nanomaterials in Table 6 as evident from their increased Isteady values [NiO/graphene (0.20 mA cm−2) [139], NiS@CNFs (1.10 mA cm−2) [143] and Ni−P/C (2.50 mA cm−2) [36]]. Another comparison list was also presented in Table 7 when examining the aforementioned electrochemical parameters for ethylene glycol electro-oxidation at some relevant nanocatalysts in the literature [14,19,20,144,145]. Promising results were still measured at our 60Ni40Mn@CNFs nanomaterial to open the door for further extended studies based on designating binary and ternary transition metallic nanocatalysts as anode materials in fuel cells applications. 4 Conclusion The electrospinning protocol for mixtures of nickel and manganese acetate salts in different wt.% proportions with further calcination process at 850 °C was sufficient to prepare regular nanofibrous structures of binary metallic species on CNFs surface. Some kinetics parameters were derived for the obtained NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials to reveal the best electrochemical performance when 40 wt.% Mn was introduced. Lowered ks values were shown for electrocatalysts containing a higher Mn content. Facilitated ethylene glycol electro-oxidation reaction was observed when examining these nanocatalysts activity as anode materials in alkaline solution. The presence of manganese in all NiMn@CNFs was efficient in decreasing the onset potential for the alcohol oxidation step when compared to that at Ni@CNFs. Moreover, the corresponding chronoamperogram of 60Ni40Mn@CNFs demonstrated its enhanced steady state current density by about 17 folds after adding manganese acetate to the electrospun mixture. The promising results of these fibrous binary metallic nanoparticles encourage their future application as superior electrocatalysts for biosensing and energy production purposes. coredata.dc:description: Electrospinning technique was exploited to prepare a series of nickel-manganese alloy on carbon nanofibers [NiMn@CNFs] in various Ni:Mn wt.% ratios by using the corresponding acetate salts at 20 kV, followed by a calcination process for the obtained metallic fibrous mats at 850 °C for 5 h. The crystalline structure, morphology and chemical constituents of formed nanocomposites were determined by using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyses. The electrocatalytic activity of different NiMn@CNFs nanomaterials for oxidizing ethylene glycol molecules was evaluated in NaOH solution through cyclic voltammetry and steady state polarization measurements. The presence of increased content of manganese in NiMn@CNFs nanocomposite significantly affected its electrochemical performance. Adding 40 wt.% Mn in the synthesized nanomaterial was sufficient to achieve the optimum oxidation current density with the best stability when compared to that of Ni@CNFs. The present work opens a new route for fabricating many binary and ternary transition metals-based fibrous mats by using the electrospinning technique and examining their electrochemical activity for renewable energy applications.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of electrospun transition metallic nanofibrous mats with outstanding activity for ethylene glycol electro-oxidation in alkaline solution
